title: ripgrep fails to build with MUSL on Linux since the nightly release on 2019-03-15

labels.name: A-linkage
labels.description: Area: linking into static, shared libraries and binaries

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-nightly
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from stable to nightly.

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: regression-from-stable-to-beta
labels.description: Performance or correctness regression from stable to beta.

body:
The last successful build was with the Rust nightly released on 2019-03-14 (bc44841ad): https://travis-ci.org/BurntSushi/ripgrep/jobs/506631861

The first failing build was with the Rust nightly released on 2019-03-15 (52e885628): https://travis-ci.org/BurntSushi/ripgrep/jobs/507121811

There weren't any changes on my end. (Last commit to ripgrep master was 2019-03-03.)

Here's the pertinent error:

```
          collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
```

Unfortunately, I can't seem to reproduce this on my local system. One possible difference between my local system (Archlinux) and the Ubuntu CI on Travis is that Ubuntu might be using an older version of `musl-gcc` via the `musl-tools` package. I have `musl 1.1.21` locally. According to the logs in the link above, CI is using `musl 0.9.15` (for both the last successful build and the first failing build).
